name: Description produce
format: Our proposal of the Produce part of the PnPr architecture is presented in Fig. 2. At the top, in the green rectangle with dashed line, are the (5) steps of Produce, which can be interpreted from left to right: communicate (6), select (7), analyze (8), compose (9) and manage (10). At the bottom of the green rectangle with dashed line in Fig. 2, the number of steps is associated with their specific functions in the PnPr architecture, maintaining the same numbering.

info:
CRUD Methods (Create, Read, Update and Delete)


Registry – A centralized storage object that holds dynamic variables, configurations, and other essential application data. 
It serves as a single source of truth for managing runtime settings, environment parameters, and metadata, allowing seamless access and updates across different components of the application. 
The Registry ensures consistency, flexibility, and maintainability by providing a structured way to store and retrieve critical information.

name: Options
func:
msg.payload = {
  op1: Math.floor(Math.random() * 100),
  op2: 11 + Math.floor(Math.random() * 10),
  op3: Math.floor(Math.random() * 50),
  op4: Math.floor(Math.random() * 75),
  op5: Math.floor(Math.random() * 30),
  op6: Math.floor(Math.random() * 20),
  op7: Math.floor(Math.random() * 99),
  op8: Math.floor(Math.random() * 80),
  op9: Math.floor(Math.random() * 60),
  op10: Math.floor(Math.random() * 40),
  sensor: global.get("registry.sensor.aas.idShortAsset"),
  sensorValue: global.get("registry.sensor.aas.value"),
  controller: global.get("registry.controller.aas.idShortAsset"),
  actuator: global.get("registry.actuator.aas.idShortAsset")
};


return msg;

name: Applications
Description
format:
A total integrated networked environment is one of the I4.0 pillars. Creating I4.0 applications in the Produce part requires a standardized and automatic communication among assets.

The sixth step in the Produce process, as depicted in Fig. (6), involves utilizing service composer software compatible with the asset communication protocol and their respective information models of the PnPr architecture to establish a communication channel for creating automation applications.

In our proposal, Node-RED and the 4diac IDE for IEC 61499 were chosen as the composers due to their industry acceptance and communication support for our PnPr architecture (microservice, OPC UA, and HTTP).

name: Description
format:
The seventh step in the Produce process, as illustrated in Fig. (7) (green rectangle), involves application composers issuing a scanner request to detect all assets present in the network.

Upon receiving a response, which includes their properties, capacities, and other structured information according to the information model (AAS), the data can be organized into an Asset Library, as depicted in Fig. (7).

In our proposal, we use the Node Package Manager (NPM) and 4diac for encapsulating and distributing custom-created libraries and/or blocks within the Node-RED and IEC61499 development environments.

name: Description analyze
format:
In the eighth step in Produce in Fig. (8) (green rectangle), the compositor analyzes the identity, functionalities, and requirements of the asset(s).

The asset manager data structure in Fig. (8) (E.g., Motor) supports the representation of the physical and the information world, allowing the change of asset parameters, as well as the creation of asset simulation models for enabling the creation of Digital Twins (DT).

name: Description compose
format:
Industrial service-oriented applications mostly rely on the orchestration procedure. The ninth step in Produce in Fig. (9) (green rectangle) is related to the composition of applications in the PnPr architecture.

As in an "orchestra", the composer defines a sequence in which the assets will relate, composing the required application in Fig. (9) (Asset Composer).

name: Description manage
format:
The tenth and last step in Produce in Fig. (10) (green rectangle) occurs after defining the order in the asset’s composition. The execution of the application can occur manually, where each step of the program is controlled and initiated by the user.

Furthermore, there is automatic execution, where the program is configured to operate autonomously, without direct user intervention. Actions are performed according to a set of predefined instructions or rules.

name: Tasks
info:
Ricardo
[ ] construir o diagrama de sequencia de todas etapas.
[ ] focar mais no frontend do que no backend, porque o pessoal vai saber ver bem mais diagrama de sequencia ou fluxograma do que o codigo em si.
[ ] descrever novas funcionalidades de programação, como operar. Imagens locais.
[ ] simplificar analyze esta dando muito get set a toa, ou pode dar apenas da variavel desejada
[ ] deixar as fontes do dashboard de uma maneira que quando tirado o printscreen e depois reduzido para 16cm a fonte fique com 8pt.
[ ] testar aasxserver se escreve opc na ultima versão.
[ ] deletar os templates do dash que nao estao usando ou ocultar apenas os que nao tem nada.
[ ] fazer backup no github e versionmento 0.0.5  colocar 1.0.0.
[ ] colocar na rasp do dashboard rasp 4 64.

Matheus

[ ] Tank Level         LIT125 roxo         SENOIDE                lv122 100%
[ ] Reservoir Pressure PIT129 verde        QUADRADA PWM 50%       lv122 Nao se aplica
[ ] Pipe Flow          PIT116 azul         TRIANGULAR             lv122 100%

[ ] adicionar um contador de amostras coletadas.
[ ] adicionar um led dizendo que a gravaçao começo/terminou ou switch, o mesmo para startar o controle. Pois nao da pra saber se realmente quando pressionamos se começou.
[ ] mover o tipo de onda para o select, deixando a configuração para o analize, padronização dos assets.
[ ] mover todos os tempos, intervalos, ou triggers ou repete 1x tudo para o registry e colocar link in link out, pois tem muitos que se repetem para simplificar os contadores.
[ ] adicionar operational requirements quando a malha é selecionada aparece o default.
[ ] se sobrar tempo adicionar influxdb copia e cola logica, e mudar as variaveis.

txt

url
format:
<script>
    (function(scope) {
    let ultimaUrl = null;

    scope.$watch('msg', function(msg) {
        if (
            msg &&
            msg.trigger === true &&
            typeof msg.payload === 'string' &&
            msg.payload.startsWith('http://186.217.146.208:18105/Export_SpxPv') &&
            msg.payload !== ultimaUrl
        ) {
            ultimaUrl = msg.payload;
            window.open(msg.payload, '_blank');

            // limpa o conteúdo para não reutilizar em outro momento
            setTimeout(function() {
                scope.send({ reset: true });
            }, 500); // dá um pequeno delay pro link abrir primeiro
        }
    });
})(scope);
</script>

url
format:
<script>
    (function(scope) {
    let ultimaUrl = null;

    scope.$watch('msg', function(msg) {
        if (
            msg &&
            msg.trigger === true &&
            typeof msg.payload === 'string' &&
            msg.payload.startsWith('http://186.217.146.208:18105/Export_MVxError') &&
            msg.payload !== ultimaUrl
        ) {
            ultimaUrl = msg.payload;
            window.open(msg.payload, '_blank');

            // limpa o conteúdo para não reutilizar em outro momento
            setTimeout(function() {
                scope.send({ reset: true });
            }, 500); // dá um pequeno delay pro link abrir primeiro
        }
    });
})(scope);
</script>

name: Return of query
func:
let csvLine = `${msg.variable};${msg.topic}\n`;  // Cria uma nova linha com os valores
msg.payload = csvLine;  // Coloca a linha CSV como a carga útil
msg.append = true;  // Adiciona ao final do arquivo, sem sobrescrever
return msg;
